  Line 742:

```
menuStyle = getComputedStyle ? getComputedStyle(menu) : false,
```

Results in the following error in IE8:

```
'getComputedStyle' is undefined
```

Using a globally scoped polyfill messes with jQuery (it runs non-IE8-safe code if getComputedStyle is defined), so I got around this by doing the following:

```
 var getComputedStyle = window.getComputedStyle || function(el, pseudo) {
        this.el = el;
        this.getPropertyValue = function(prop) {
          var re = /(\-([a-z]){1})/g;
          if (prop == 'float') prop = 'styleFloat';
          if (re.test(prop)) {
            prop = prop.replace(re, function () {
              return arguments[2].toUpperCase();
            });
          }
          return el.currentStyle[prop] ? el.currentStyle[prop] : null;
        };
        return this;
      };
      var liHeight = a.offsetHeight,
          headerHeight = header ? header.offsetHeight : 0,
          searchHeight = search ? search.offsetHeight : 0,
          actionsHeight = actions ? actions.offsetHeight : 0,
          doneButtonHeight = doneButton ? doneButton.offsetHeight : 0,
          dividerHeight = $(divider).outerHeight(true),
          // fall back to jQuery if getComputedStyle is not supported
          menuStyle = getComputedStyle(menu),
          $menu = menuStyle ? $(menu) : null,
          menuPadding = parseInt(menuStyle ? menuStyle.paddingTop : $menu.css('paddingTop')) +
                        parseInt(menuStyle ? menuStyle.paddingBottom : $menu.css('paddingBottom')) +
                        parseInt(menuStyle ? menuStyle.borderTopWidth : $menu.css('borderTopWidth')) +
                        parseInt(menuStyle ? menuStyle.borderBottomWidth : $menu.css('borderBottomWidth')),
          menuExtras =  menuPadding + 
                        parseInt(menuStyle ? menuStyle.marginTop : $menu.css('marginTop')) + 
                        parseInt(menuStyle ? menuStyle.marginBottom : $menu.css('marginBottom')) + 2;
```

This creates a locally scoped function called getComputedStyle if the globally-scoped version on the window object isn't present. We want it locally scoped only because, like I mentioned before, jQuery does bad things if it finds a globally scoped version.
 The issue with that fix is that menuStyle then is set to false, which means $menu is set to null, which means lines 725-731 die when calling the css() method on $menu.

I have unhidden the native `select` element. If you change the `select` element, then both event handlers are called. However, if you change the Bootstrap-select element, then only the jQuery event handler is called (the 'change' event registered using `addEventListener()` is never fired).

One fix would be to replace `that.$element.change();` on line 1046 with this:

`that.$element[0].dispatchEvent(new Event('change'));`

Now the 'change' event is properly fired regardless of whether you use jQuery or vanilla JS to register it, as demonstrated here: http://jsfiddle.net/10basetom/21wfkmdL/

Note that the `new Event()` constructor is not supported in IE, so if you want IE support then you can create the event the [old-fashioned way](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Guide/Events/Creating_and_triggering_events#The_old-fashioned_way).

  **Problem description**

Currently, when user clicks "Select All" or "Deselect All" buttons, following code is called:

```
1052   selectAll: function () {
1053       this.findLis();
1054       this.$lis.not('.divider').not('.disabled').not('.selected').filter(':visible').find('a').click();
1055   },
1056 
1057   deselectAll: function () {
1058       this.findLis();
1059       this.$lis.not('.divider').not('.disabled').filter('.selected').filter(':visible').find('a').click();
1060   },
```

Basically, a click event is invoked multiple times and as a result, client JavaScript code receives multiple "change" events. If these change events are connected to some "slow task", such as Ajax calls to server (for example in order to fill in second select with data based on the selection in a first select), performance suffers and additional code must be written in order to better synchronize multiple Ajax calls.

**Solution proposal**

Adding a new option `aggregateChangeEvents: true/false, default = true`. If the property is set to `false`, the component keeps the current behavior (in case someone relies on it in code). If the property is set to `true` (default), only the code from the click handler is called on all items (no "virtual clicks" are invoked).

Solution affects only "multiselect" selects. However, looking at the code, this change will require some "careful surgery". I will take the issue over if required (just call "Go!" in case you cannot pull solution of the sleve:)) but will ask for a thorough code review after I submit pull request...

I'll just bounce some ideas off you just in case it interests you, basically the idea is to break selectpicker down into 3 MVC like components, one model and two views, allowing more flexible setups.

### The model

The model would be a JS object which stores the current value of the select, it would have an array of callbacks which would be called at any time the value changes. Depending on the list view implementation, it would also store the original `select` element and notify changes made to the options.

### The button view

The button view would just be a basically be a bootstrap style button which can be connected to the select model, when the value changes, the button updates it's appearance. The button can also optionally be connected to a list view (and would be by default if one constructs the selectpicker using the regular API). The button would also have the option of setting the size of it's connected dropdown menu, or letting the dropdown menu have it's own natural size.

### The list view

The list view is the thing which pops up when you show the selectpicker, it needs to be connected to a model and it could be used independently without a button view, allowing one to create completely custom views and showing the listview manually.

### Problems

There are a bunch of problems when considering doing a proper MVC within a jquery plugin, which is rather functional and has the opinion that state should be in the DOM instead of managed by a proper JS object.
- Does the model store the hidden `select` element and propagate changes to the views about changes the user makes when they call `refresh` ? Probably it must.
- Does one allow creating multiple `list view` widgets ? Perhaps the implementation is simplified by enforcing that there must be a 1:1 relationship between the list view and the model ?

In any case, I realise this would mean a large refactor and I don't expect it to write itself by magick, and unfortunately I don't have the time to focus on this myself, I just wanted to leave some ideas in the comment here.

- "doneButton": true / false - Indicates if the multiple select should display done button. The option works only on multiple selects (see "multiple" attribute).

 The reason bootstrap-select is so slow (and this will go for any of the select box stylers like select2, chosen, etc...) is that they replicate a select box.  It is not possible to make a select box look like bootstrap-select does while just styling the original select.  So, instead we fake it.

To fake it though, every `<option>` tag is made using 6 html tags.  So 1,000 options becomes 6,000 elements.  6,000 elements to show and hide (when opening the select picker), and searching (assuming you have that on since you have so may elements).  There is no way to realistically speed this up, to be able to style the dropdown you will always need more than 1 element.  There is also no way to style the original select picker to look like your other bootstrap-select dropdowns.

Now saying all that, I ran into this problem as well and wrote a plugin called [Ajax-Bootstrap-Select](https://github.com/truckingsim/Ajax-Bootstrap-Select) that goes on top of bootstrap-select which adds ajax support to the search box.  You can still use all the options of bootstrap-select (like for labels, and custom html, etc...) and you can send as many elements as want since it through ajax (for instance if someone searches for A, only send the first 25 elements if that's what makes you happy).  This makes the page load quicker and the interaction as well since you **don't** load the 1,000 elements on the page.

Obviously if you use that plugin, you'll need to implements a searchable API on the server for the dropdown, but if you are generating 1k elements I imagine you have a list you can search through fairly easily and return the filtered results.

> selectOffsetTop = that.$newElement.offset().top - $window.scrollTop();
> selectOffsetBot = $window.height() - selectOffsetTop - selectHeight;
> The problem here is that `$window.height()` gives the height of the full window (with scroll) and `selectOffsetTop` gives only visible part (without scroll).
> That's why the value of `selectOffsetBot` will be calculated incorrectly what will produce incorrect work of `.dropup` class.

In my situation I had dropdown absolutely on the bottom of the page and I had these values as follow:

> selectOffsetTop = 840
> selectOffsetBot = 1240
> Thought `selectOffsetBot` should have been `0`.

The fix should be like this:

> selectOffsetBot = $window.height() - that.$newElement.offset().top - selectHeight;

 Been using bootstrap select with asp.net for a while now, code to make it work, while also adding 'option group' functionality to asp dropdownlist: ( VB code)

```
Public Class DropDownListAdapter
    Inherits System.Web.UI.WebControls.Adapters.WebControlAdapter
    Protected Overrides Sub RenderContents(writer As HtmlTextWriter)

            Dim list As DropDownList = TryCast(Me.Control, DropDownList)

            Dim currentOptionGroup As String
            Dim renderedOptionGroups As New List(Of String)()

            For Each item As ListItem In list.Items
                If item.Attributes("OptionGroup") Is Nothing Then
                    RenderListItem(item, writer)
                Else
                    currentOptionGroup = item.Attributes("OptionGroup")

                    If renderedOptionGroups.Contains(currentOptionGroup) Then
                        RenderListItem(item, writer)
                    Else
                        If renderedOptionGroups.Count > 0 Then
                            RenderOptionGroupEndTag(writer)
                        End If

                        RenderOptionGroupBeginTag(currentOptionGroup, writer)
                        renderedOptionGroups.Add(currentOptionGroup)

                        RenderListItem(item, writer)
                    End If
                End If
            Next

            If renderedOptionGroups.Count > 0 Then
                RenderOptionGroupEndTag(writer)
            End If
    End Sub

    Private Sub RenderOptionGroupBeginTag(name As String, writer As HtmlTextWriter)
        writer.WriteBeginTag("optgroup")
        writer.WriteAttribute("label", name)
        writer.Write(HtmlTextWriter.TagRightChar)
        writer.WriteLine()
    End Sub

    Private Sub RenderOptionGroupEndTag(writer As HtmlTextWriter)
        writer.WriteEndTag("optgroup")
        writer.WriteLine()
    End Sub

    Private Sub RenderListItem(item As ListItem, writer As HtmlTextWriter)
        writer.WriteBeginTag("option")
        writer.WriteAttribute("value", item.Value, True)

        If item.Selected Then
            writer.WriteAttribute("selected", "selected", False)
        End If

        For Each key As String In item.Attributes.Keys
            writer.WriteAttribute(key, item.Attributes(key))
        Next

        writer.Write(HtmlTextWriter.TagRightChar)
        HttpUtility.HtmlEncode(item.Text, writer)
        writer.WriteEndTag("option")
        writer.WriteLine()
    End Sub
End Class
```

 This problem also exists on IE9, and the current fix doesn't completely solve the problem.
The shifting of the arguments causes both the local variables to change (_option_ and _event_).
That means the check for (_option_ == 'undefined') only works if _event_ is undefined, as _option_ becomes _event_, and _event_ becomes whatever followed it.
(and there are arguments that follow _event_ in certain cases. IE: _setStyle()_)
It is probably best to not override a parameter with a local variable of the same name, as for some reason the JS interpreter for IE9 alters the local value after the shift.
I refactored the code to use __option_ and __event_ throughout instead, and that seems to solve the problem:

  This issue has been raised previously: https://github.com/silviomoreto/bootstrap-select/issues/298

However, the solution previously proposed (manipulate the cached `data-content` directly using `.data()`) requires the user of bootstrap-select to:
- Be aware that this caching is occurring
- Discover the values in the `.data()` store
- Track all changes in the DOM to `data-content` 
- "Fix-up" the cached values in `.data()` if and when changes are made.

This isn't so onerous if your app is using jQuery to directly make all changes to the DOM (assuming this case was actually documented).  But this approach falls apart entirely when the `<option data-content="{{someThing}}">` is being changed/manipulated indirectly by a template-driven library such as [Ractive](http://www.ractivejs.org/) or [Meteor](https://github.com/meteor/meteor/wiki/New-Template-Engine-Preview). It's important to note that these libs do not rerender entire templates on any data change; rather they make minimal surgical updates to the DOM when data changes. So above, when the value of `someThing` changes, just the `data-content` attr of the element updates, as though you used `.attr()` directly.

These frameworks are obviously unaware of the data caching, and it destroys the abstraction provided by the template system to need to dive in and manually fix-up the cached version of `data-content` after a template driven change.

I agree with the OP in the original issue that there should be a way to turn off the caching behavior, or alternatively to turn-on a "automatically check for changes" behavior.

  To limit the possible collisions between two plugins that make use of similar data attribute names, it is good to namespace our data attributes.

This PR introduces the `select` namespace for all data attributes in the original select element and its options. That is accomplish by reusing data retrival code from eterniccode's [bootstrap-datepicker](https://github.com/eternicode/bootstrap-datepicker/blob/b1775813f4e8e23775b7d389044f9573bc3f4b55/js/bootstrap-datepicker.js#L1263) plugin.

That means that all the data attributes must now be prefixed with `select`, i.e `data-live-search` become `data-select-live-search` (see test.html).

This will allow multiple plugins to use the same option names without issue.

At the moment, the selection is breaking compatibility, so would need to be included into the next major version (according to semver), but backwards compatibility can be easily added to the code.
 Note: the documentation will have to be updated to reflect the new syntax.

 Ok, after lots of wondering for the best way to handle the issue I came up with the above commit (unfortunately it does not solve the problem the way I wanted but at least provides some functionality which might help in most cases).

So the plugin will monitor `focusin` and `focusout` on its wrapper element to try to decide on when it gets focus and when it looses focus. These two events are also fired on the original element together with `focus` and `blur` which only fire when the control is considered to get or loose focus respectively. **The caveat** is that all these events are fired using `triggerHandler` and not `trigger` and because of this **they will not bubble** up the DOM tree and event delegation will not work. The reason for this decision is that using `trigger("focus")` would actually try to focus the element (causing side effects) and not just fire the event on it. And even that would be if it worked at all - but triggering "focus" on a hidden element in fact has no effect (in Chrome/Mac)! So the alternative was `triggerHandler` which at least works and causes no undesirable side effects.

  Hi, I stumbled upon an odd issue that might not affect too many people but if you have a select inside a bootstrap modal and a data-container set outside the modal (ie, body) IE will have trouble with the keyboard focus commands.

I figured out that bootstrap wires an event to document called 'focusin.modal' which prevents anything outside the modal from focusing. I was able to override this anti-focus by adding a stop propagation to this bit of code. This fixed the keyboard commands in IE (tested back to IE8 w/ dev tools).

``` javascript
$(document)
        .data('keycount', 0)
        .on('keydown', '[data-toggle=dropdown], [role=menu]', Selectpicker.prototype.keydown)
        .on('focusin.modal', '[data-toggle=dropdown], [role=menu]', function (e) { e.stopPropagation() });
```

Thanks!

 The issue is that the enter control is re-rendered on every select. And the complexity of render() is O(n). So the time grows linearly. On my system, the mix and max per iteration time for one of the loops in render() is 1ms to 58ms. That's a pretty large variance.

Re-rendering on every select is overkill. Unfortunately I've spent too much time on this already, and won't be able to refactor the code.
 Just by saving the list of LIs instead of doing a find on each setSelected and setDisabled cut down the time for render() by 60%

``` javascript
setSelected: function setSelected(index, selected) {
    if (this.$lis == null) this.$lis = this.$menu.find('li');
    $(this.$lis[index]).toggleClass('selected', selected);
},

setDisabled: function setDisabled(index, disabled) {
    if (this.$lis == null) this.$lis = this.$menu.find('li');
    if (disabled) {
        $(this.$lis[index]).addClass('disabled').find('a').attr('href','#').attr('tabindex',-1);
    } else {
        $(this.$lis[index]).removeClass('disabled').find('a').removeAttr('href').attr('tabindex',0);
    }
},
```

``` javascript
$(document).ready(function() {

    if(selectPicker.data('open')) {
      selectPicker.data('open', false);
      // onClose callback

      selectPicker.data('open', true);
      // onOpen callback
    }
  });
```

``` javascript
                    var options = selectPickerOptions.options,

                        optionsValue = selectPickerOptions.optionsValue,
                        optionsCaption = selectPickerOptions.optionsCaption;
                    if (ko.utils.unwrapObservable(options).length > 0) {
                        ko.bindingHandlers.options.update(element, options, ko.observable({ optionsText: optionsText, optionsValue: optionsValue, optionsCaption: optionsCaption }));
                    }
                }
                if (ko.isObservable(valueAccessor())) {
                    ko.bindingHandlers.value.update(element, valueAccessor);
                }
                $(element).selectpicker('refresh');
            }
        }
    };
```

You can call this in 3 ways. If you just want to add the basic selectpicker functionality to a dropdown in your view:

```
<select data-bind="selectPicker: true">
    <option>Option 1</option>
    <option>Option 2</option>
</select>
```

If you want to bind the selected value to an observable:

```
<select data-bind="selectPicker: myObservable">
    <option value="1">Option 1</option>
    <option value="2">Option 2</option>
</select>
```

Or if you're binding to an observable, and the options in your dropdown are also being generated by another observableArray in your viewmodel:

```
<select data-bind="selectPicker: myObservable, selectPickerOptions: { options: myObservableArray, optionsText: 'myTextField', optionsValue: 'myValueField', optionsCaption: 'Please select...' }"></select>
```

The latter basically implements the built-in Knockout options binding.

 I've updated the binding since I last posted - this is the version I now use and it seems to work well in all the scenarios I use it:

``` javascript
/*
    * Custom Knockout binding to apply the selectpicker widget (bootstrap-select) to a bound dropdown and 
    * refresh it when the contents of the dropdown change.
    *
    * The binding can be used in two ways:
    *
    * 1. If you don't want to bind the dropdown's selected option to an observable, just use data-bind="selectPicker: true"
    * 2. If you wish to bind the dropdown's selected option to an observable, so that when a different option is selected 
    *    in the list it updates the observable, use data-bind="selectPicker: myObservable".
    *    If the options in the dropdown are generated from an observableArray, you can wrap the standard Knockout options binding parameters 
    *    in a selectPickerOptions object 
    *
    *    ie. data-bind="selectPicker: myObservable, selectPickerOptions: { options: myOptionsObservableArray, optionsText: 'arrayTextField', optionsValue: 'arrayValueField', optionsCaption: 'Please select...', disabledCondition: someBooleanExpression, resetOnDisabled: true|false }"
    *
    *    Note the two further parameters in the selectPickerOptions object, disabledCondition and resetOnDisabled. If provided, disabledCondition should be a boolean expression, that when evaluated as true will cause the selectpicker to be disabled.
    *    The resetOnDisabled parameter, if true, will cause the selected index of the dropdown to be reset to zero when it is disabled.
    *
    * Note requires that bootstrap-select.js is included in the view
    */
    ko.bindingHandlers.selectPicker = {
        init: function (element, valueAccessor, allBindingsAccessor) {
            if ($(element).is('select')) {
                if (ko.isObservable(valueAccessor())) {
                    if ($(element).prop('multiple') && $.isArray(ko.utils.unwrapObservable(valueAccessor()))) {
                        // in the case of a multiple select where the valueAccessor() is an observableArray, call the default Knockout selectedOptions binding
                        ko.bindingHandlers.selectedOptions.init(element, valueAccessor, allBindingsAccessor);
                    }
                    else {
                        // regular select and observable so call the default value binding
                        ko.bindingHandlers.value.init(element, valueAccessor, allBindingsAccessor);
                    }
                }
                $(element).addClass('selectpicker').selectpicker();
            }
        },
        update: function (element, valueAccessor, allBindingsAccessor) {
            if ($(element).is('select')) {
                var selectPickerOptions = allBindingsAccessor().selectPickerOptions;
                if (typeof selectPickerOptions !== 'undefined' && selectPickerOptions !== null) {
                    var options = selectPickerOptions.options,
                        optionsText = selectPickerOptions.optionsText,
                        optionsValue = selectPickerOptions.optionsValue,
                        optionsCaption = selectPickerOptions.optionsCaption,
                        isDisabled = selectPickerOptions.disabledCondition || false,
                        resetOnDisabled = selectPickerOptions.resetOnDisabled || false;
                    if (ko.utils.unwrapObservable(options).length > 0) {
                        // call the default Knockout options binding
                        ko.bindingHandlers.options.update(element, options, ko.observable({ optionsText: optionsText, optionsValue: optionsValue, optionsCaption: optionsCaption }));
                    }
                    if (isDisabled && resetOnDisabled) {
                        // the dropdown is disabled and we need to reset it to its first option
                        $(element).selectpicker('val', $(element).children('option:first').val());
                    }
                    $(element).prop('disabled', isDisabled);
                }
                if (ko.isObservable(valueAccessor())) {
                    if ($(element).prop('multiple') && $.isArray(ko.utils.unwrapObservable(valueAccessor()))) {
                        // in the case of a multiple select where the valueAccessor() is an observableArray, call the default Knockout selectedOptions binding
                        ko.bindingHandlers.selectedOptions.update(element, valueAccessor);
                    }
                    else {
                        // call the default Knockout value binding
                        ko.bindingHandlers.value.update(element, valueAccessor);
                    }
                }

                $(element).selectpicker('refresh');
            }
        }
    };

```

1 - the div containing bootstrap-select is display:none on init. Select position provided by `this.$newElement.offset().top` is wrong (so is select height, which is 0px when hidden).
2 - on clicking edit button (pencil), the display:none property is overriden, and create empty space under the page.
3 - when toggling tabs again, it fix the problem (because I trigger refresh on Pencil button click).

Here is the Event Stack:
- Page load (div `display:none`)
- bootstrap-select init
- setSize calculates MaxHeight (offset given is [0,0] so maxHeight is too much)
- on click display, display: block, and selectpicker('refresh') BUT...
- empty space appears because old size of DropMenu is considered by browser... _My collapse tabed content is overflow visible when shown_.
- DropMenu has correct height (correctly refreshed) but empty space remain... It is a problem because if we scroll, select refreshes, and can grow...
- when toggle tab, the content disappears (overflow hidden) and appears again, wonsidering new Hieght of DropMenu

I'm conscious that my issue is very specific... but the calculation of setSize can be wrong in some case.
My fix was to set a minimum height (instead of windowHeight - 0) for display:none select, and suppose that a refresh is done when displayed.

I hope this can help possible issues when using hidden selects.
 I can sum up a little the thing:
- If select is in a display:none DIV on init
  - window Height is set
  - Show Div: DropMenu height is pageHeight (creating space at page bottom) because wrong offset
  - Show Div THEN refresh: Menu Height is OK, but page still consider old height -> empty space
  - Refresh THEN show div: as on init - Wrong height

With a fix:
- If select is in a display:none DIV on init
  - Minimum Height is set (typically fixed rows, or 0px)
  - Show Div: DropMenu height is minimum Height, creating no glitches
  - Show Div THEN Refresh: Menu Height is as high as possible, maybe browser still consider old height (which is minimum, so no strange behavior, it could create empty space, but it would be appropriate)
  - Refresh THEN show div: as on init - Minimum height

  Hey Silvio,

I have added support for Multi-select to your plugin, however, as you can imainge it required quite a hefty refactor  - so im not sure how well it will merge, if at all you want to merge it, however, this is what is supported in this fork:

**New Classes**
The class `show-tick` on a `select` element will show a tick icon on the selected  row(s).

The class `show-menu-arrow` on a `select` will add the small top arrow on the drop down menu.

**Attributes**
The attribute `multiple='multiple'` on the `select` will enable multiple selection within the drop down, and enable ticks icons by default.

The attribute `title='My Default test'` on the `select` will set the initial prompt text for the main button if no value has been set yet.

**js Properties**
The property `selectedText` in the JS constructor will set how the selected text is displayed.  Values are:
    1. `value` - will show the selected value, or comma delimited values if multiple select.
    2. `count` - will show 'x of x Selected' if multiple selecte.
    3. `count>n` - will show the 'x of x Selected' text only when more then `n` have actually been selected.  Eg values if the `selectedText` is 'count>2', and the selected values are 'One', and 'Two' then the selected text is 'One,Two'.  Once there are more than 2 selected, it will say something like '3 of 4 Selected' .

``` javascript
$(".selectpicker.one").selectpicker({ selectedText:'count' });
$(".selectpicker.two").selectpicker({ selectedText:'count>4' });
```

**js Methods**
The method `val` has been exposed as part of the plugin, which will update the `select` value, and trigger a render of the plugin at the same time (this is because the jquery .val() does not trigger onChange.

``` javascript
$(".selectpicker").selectpicker("val", "Two");
```

I also exposed the new `render` method, that allows the dev to still manually modify the `select`, and then call `render` themselves when done:

``` javascript
$(".selectpicker").val("Two");
$(".selectpicker").selectpicker("render");
```

**Refactor**
To enable easy updating of the component, and easier branching of logic depending on multi select / single select, I refactored the creation and reload methods into one main method that creates the child Lis, which is called both by the `create` method and the `reload` method now.  

This ment reworking the templates slightly, and adding elements via JQ rather than string replace of the template.

I then created a `render` method that simply updates the state of the LI list based on the state of the `select` element.

**Basic Demo HTML**
You can run this to test it out :

``` html
<html>
    <head>
        <script language="javascript" src="http://code.jquery.com/jquery-1.9.1.min.js"></script>
        <script src="http://netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/twitter-bootstrap/2.3.1/js/bootstrap.min.js"></script>
        <link href="http://netdna.bootstrapcdn.com/twitter-bootstrap/2.3.1/css/bootstrap-combined.min.css" rel="stylesheet">

        <script language="javascript" src="bootstrap-select.min.js"></script>
        <link type="text/css" rel="stylesheet" href="bootstrap-select.min.css" />

        <script>
            $(document).ready(function() {

               $(".selectpicker").not(".count-example").selectpicker();

                $(".selectpicker.count-example.default-count").selectpicker( {
                    selectedText:'count' 
                });

               $(".selectpicker.count-example").selectpicker( {
                    selectedText:'count>2' 
                });
            });
        </script>
    </head>
    <body>
        <div>
            <b>default</b>
            <select class='selectpicker'>
                <option>One</option>
                <option>Two</option>
                <option>Three</option>
            </select>
        </div>

        <div>
            <b>With arrow in menu</b>
            <select class='selectpicker show-tick show-menu-arrow'>
                <option>One</option>
                <option>Two</option>
                <option>Three</option>
            </select>
        </div>

        <div>
            <b>With tick</b>
            <select class='selectpicker show-tick'>
                <option>One</option>
                <option>Two</option>
                <option>Three</option>
            </select>
        </div>

        <div>
            <b>Multiple</b>
            <select multiple='multiple' class='selectpicker'>
                <option>One</option>
                <option>Two</option>
                <option>Three</option>
            </select>
        </div>

        <div>
            <b>Default text</b>
            <select multiple='multiple' class='selectpicker' title='Select one or more...'>
                <option>One</option>
                <option>Two</option>
                <option>Three</option>
            </select>
        </div>

        <div>
            <b>Selected text as count</b>
            <select multiple='multiple' class='selectpicker count-example default-count' title='Select one or more...'>
                <option>One</option>
                <option>Two</option>
                <option>Three</option>
            </select>
        </div>

        <div>
            <b>Selected text as count above 2</b>
            <select id="test" multiple='multiple' class='selectpicker count-example' title='Select one or more...'>
```

I wanted to create a dropdown similar to YouTube's "Date Range" dropdown. It does two things that greatly improve the way the options are listed.
1. It adds separators to group the items
2. Options can have custom text added that isn't relevant to the option's text itself.

![Analytics - YouTube](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/241816/132462/77822bce-7085-11e2-9832-9b349c179340.jpg)

I don't know if it's something you want or not, but I added the [Jasmine testing framework](https://github.com/pivotal/jasmine) to hopefully prevent breaking existing functionality. If you don't like Jasmine, or using the [jasmine-gem](https://github.com/pivotal/jasmine-gem) to run server, you can just grab the changes I made in `bootstrap-select.js`

> Note: I didn't add a compressed version because I wasn't sure which compressor you liked.

---
### How to use my changes

You can change the option's text by adding a `data-option-text` attribute. This option only applies to the dropdown menu itself. It doesn't modify the the text added to the button.

``` html
<select>
  <option value="week" data-option-text="This week <span>Sunday – today</span>">This week</option>
</select>
```

To add a separator you need to set `data-separator` to `true`. The value and text within then `<option>` tag is omitted.

``` html
<select>
  <option data-separator="true">---</option>
</select>
```

To style the separator I just added this to my code.

``` css
.dropdown-menu ul .separator {
  background: #ddd;
  height: 1px;
  display: block;
  margin: 5px 0;
}
```
